titleText.ttltext: Efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of a recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV) in children aged 2-17 years: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Instituto de Estudos em Saúde Coletiva, Universidade Federal Do Rio de Janeiro

paras: Background Randomised controlled trials have evaluated the recombinant tetravalent dengue @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (CYD-TDV). However, individual results may have little power to identify differences among the populations studied. Objective To evaluate efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV in the prevention of dengue in children aged 2-17 years. Design @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. Data sources @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end (from 1950 to 5 December 2018), @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end (from 1947 to 5 December 2018) and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end (from 1993 to 5 December 2018). Eligibility criteria of studies Randomised trials comparing efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV with placebo or other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for preventing dengue cases in children aged 2-17 years. Outcome measures Efficacy, immunogenicity and safety of CYD-TDV. Study appraisal and methods Calculations were made of relative risk (RR) and mean difference (MD) for dichotomous and continuous outcomes, respectively. All estimates were calculated considering a 95% CI estimate. A p<0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results Nine studies involving 34 248 participants were included. The overall efficacy of CYD-TDV was 60% (RR 0.40 (0.30 to 0.54)). Serotype-specific efficacy of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end was 51% for dengue virus type-1 (DENV-1) (RR 0.49 (0.39 to 0.63)); 34% for DENV-2 (RR 0.66 (0.50 to 0.86)); 75% for DENV-3 (RR 0.25 (0.18 to 0.35)) and 77% for DENV-4 (RR 0.23 (0.15 to 0.34)). Overall immunogenicity (MD) of CYD-TDV was 225.13 (190.34 to 259.93). Serotype-specific immunogenicity was: DENV-1: 176.59 (123.36 to 229.83); DENV-2: 294.21 (181.98 to 406.45); DENV-3: 258.78 (146.72 to 370.84) and DENV-4: 189.35 (141.11 to 237.59). The most common adverse events were headache and pain at the injection site. Limitations The main limitation of this study was unclear or incomplete data. Conclusions and implications of key findings CYD-TDV is considered safe and able to partially protect children and adolescents against four serotypes of DENV for a 1-year period. Despite this, research should prioritise improvements in @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy, thus proving higher long-term protection against all virus serotypes.

titleText.ttltext: Effectiveness of interventions for optimising adherence to treatments for the prevention and management of scars: Protocol for a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Centre for Children's Burns and Trauma Research, Children's Health Research Centre, University of Queensland

paras: Introduction Treatments used in the management of scarring following wounds of the skin can be complex and time consuming, and patients may experience difficulties adhering to these treatments. Therefore, the aim of this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end is to identify the types of interventions that have been used to optimise adherence to treatment for preventing or reducing skin scars in adults and children and to determine the effectiveness of these interventions. Methods and @hit_startanalysis@hit_end Databases (@hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end, Web of Science and OTSeeker) will be searched using the developed search strategy to identify eligible randomised trials. Adults and children using scar treatments to prevent or manage scarring as a result of a dermal wound (which may occur following burn injury, surgery, lacerations, piercings, @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end, acne and other conditions affecting the skin) will be included. Any intervention with the potential to effect adherence will be included. Titles and abstracts located through searching will be screened by two independent reviewers. Full text of studies will also be screened to determine eligibility for final inclusion. Two reviewers will assess the quality of included studies using the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end 'risk of bias' tool. Data extraction forms will be developed and two reviewers will extract the data. A third reviewer will be used at each stage to ensure consensus is achieved. @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression will be completed if appropriate, otherwise a narrative synthesis of results will be undertaken. Ethics and dissemination No ethical approval is necessary for this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end as no patients will be directly involved. Results of this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end will be disseminated through journal publications and relevant conference presentations. PROSPERO registration number CRD42018095082.

titleText.ttltext: Perioperative Therapies-Using Repurposed Drugs to Improve Cancer Surgery Outcomes

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. All rights reserved.
paras: Aims Reducing the rate of recurrence after curative-intent surgical resection is an attractive strategy for improving long-term survival in cancer. Perioperative therapies administered in the period immediately prior to, during, or after surgery therefore hold the potential to improve overall survival. Drug repurposing is a source of therapeutic candidates for further clinical investigation. We aimed to identify noncancer drugs with the potential to be repurposed as perioperative therapies. Methods The Repurposing Drugs in Oncology repurposing database and @hit_startPubMed@hit_end were used for a literature-based search of publications related to perioperative treatment of cancer. Three clinical trials registries were also searched to identify relevant clinical trials with survival endpoints. Both the literature and trial screens were supplemented with additional data known to the authors. Results Fifty-two drugs were identified as potential perioperative therapies, with 67% having supporting human data. There are few clinical trials with survival endpoints, mainly in breast and colorectal cancers. Discussion The perioperative setting is not as well established as the neoadjuvant and adjuvant settings, making identification of relevant research and clinical trials difficult. Despite the potential benefits of such interventions, there is a need for more well-designed clinical trials, additional research, and biomarkers of response.

titleText.ttltext: Infertility after mumps infection: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Faculty of Medicine, University of Tripoli

paras: Introduction: Mumps is considered one of the major causes of male infertility. The incidence of mumps orchitis has declined dramatically since the start of the childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programme. However, some epidemics happened recently in New York 2005 and United Kingdom 2017. A mumps outbreak can result from exposure to virus carried from a country with an ongoing mumps epidemic. Objectives: To assess the prevalence of patients becoming infertile or subfertile after mumps infection. Besides, we aim to assess the distribution of mumps among the other causative agents of infertility. A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was done to assess the prevalence of the history of mumps infection and mumps orchitis rates. Methods: In April 2018, we conducted an electronic search in nine databases; to identify studies reporting subfertility or infertility after mumps infection in human. Quality assessment was performed using NIH tool for included studies. The random model was used as heterogeneity was significant, when p-value of Q statistic was <0.1 and I-squared was >50%. Dichotomous data were presented as relative risk (RR), with 95% confidence interval (CI). Publication bias was considered significant by Egger's regression test when its p-value was <0.10. The study protocol was registered in PROSPERO (CRD42016038098). Results: With 727 studies initially identified, 19 were eligible for qualitative @hit_startanalysis@hit_end and 17 for quantitative @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, with 14,594 patients were retrieved and moderate level of quality. Overall, positive history of mumps infection and mumps orchitis prevalence rates were (68.4%, 95%CI [0.568-0.781]; p=0.002 and 1.8%, [0.010-0.031]; p<0.001, respectively). Among patients with positive history of mumps infection, their azoospermia and mumps orchitis prevalence rates were (5% [0.008-0.258]; p=0.002 and 3.5% [0.000-0.773]; p=0.153, respectively). Conclusion: Mumps is a considerable cause of infection-induced infertility with a high prevalence rate of exposure. Our study can be used as a retrospective indicator of mumps orchitis rates in the past decade to compare it with the new coming studies. New primary studies are needed to evaluate current risk of mumps orchitis after mumps @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake has improved.

titleText.ttltext: Coverage of Haemophilus influenzae Type b Conjugate @hit_startVaccine@hit_end for Children in Mainland China: @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Tropical Disease Research Center, Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, Fudan University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. All rights reserved.
paras: Background: Use of Haemophilus influenzae type b conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is effective in reducing the disease burden, but its coverage in China is unclear. The aim of this @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end is to assess the coverage of Hib conjugate @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in children in Mainland China. Methods: We systematically searched @hit_startPubmed@hit_end, Web of Science, @hit_startMedline@hit_end, CNKI and Wanfang to identify studies assessing the coverage of Hib @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in Chinese children. Random-effects models were used to obtain pooled estimates for Hib @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage and @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end heterogeneity with @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression and subgroup @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. Results: Thirty-three studies that included 7,227,480 subjects in 12 provinces met our inclusion criteria. The pooled overall coverage of Hib conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end was 54.9% [95% confidence interval (CI): 52.9-57.0]. The pooled coverage for the nonlocal population (54.3%; 95% CI: 52.4-56.3) was lower than that for the local residents (62.0%; 95% CI: 58.4-65.6). The region-pooled coverage was higher in the east of China (59.7%; 95% CI: 57.3-62.1) than in the central and west parts of the country (48.5%; 95% CI: 40.6-56.4). Overall, 26.7% (95% CI: 20.1-33.2) had 1 dose only, 14.8% (95% CI: 10.0-19.6%) had 2 doses, 13.5% (95% CI: 9.1-17.8) had 3 doses and 14.3% (95% CI: 9.7-18.9) had 4 doses. Conclusions: We found a low coverage of Hib conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, particularly for the nonlocal children and those living in the central and west parts of China. Including Hib @hit_startvaccine@hit_end into the national @hit_startimmunization@hit_end program is recommended to reduce disparities in @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage.

titleText.ttltext: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Practices for Use of Hepatitis A @hit_startVaccine@hit_end for Persons Experiencing Homelessness

paras: Hepatitis A (HepA) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is recommended routinely for children at age 12-23 months, for persons who are at increased risk for hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection, and for any person wishing to obtain @hit_startimmunity@hit_end. Persons at increased risk for HAV infection include international travelers to areas with high or intermediate hepatitis A endemicity, men who have sex with men, users of injection and noninjection drugs, persons with chronic liver disease, person with clotting factor disorders, persons who work with HAV-infected primates or with HAV in a research laboratory setting, and persons who anticipate close contact with an international adoptee from a country of high or interme-diate endemicity (1-3). Persons experiencing homelessness are also at higher risk for HAV infection and severe infection-associated outcomes. On October 24, 2018, the Advisory Committee on @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Practices (ACIP)* recommended that all persons aged 1 year and older experiencing homelessness be routinely @hit_startimmunized@hit_end against HAV. The ACIP Hepatitis @hit_startVaccines@hit_end Work Group conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the evidence for administering @hit_startvaccine@hit_end to persons experiencing homelessness, which included a set of criteria assessing the benefits and adverse events associated with @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. HepA @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are highly immunogenic, and >95% of immunocompetent adults develop protective antibody within 4 weeks of receipt of 1 dose of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (1). HAV infections are acquired primarily by the fecal-oral route by either person-to-person transmission or via ingestion of contaminated food or water. Among persons experiencing homelessness, effective implementation of alternative strategies to prevent exposure to HAV, such as strict hand hygiene, is difficult because of living conditions among persons in this population. Integrating routine HepA @hit_startvaccination@hit_end into health care services for persons experiencing homelessness can reduce the size of the at-risk population over time and thereby reduce the risk for large-scale outbreaks.

titleText.ttltext: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of adult tetanus-diphtheria-acellular (Tdap) coverage among healthcare workers

affiliation.addressPart: Dr. Ovídio Pires de Campos Street, 225 – Cerqueira César, Zip Code: 05403-010

paras: During the last decades pertussis incidence raised globally. Several @hit_startvaccination@hit_end strategies targeting adults to reduce pertussis among young infants have been proposed, including @hit_startvaccination@hit_end of healthcare workers (HCWs). The aim of this study was to @hit_startanalyse@hit_end, by performing a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of @hit_startliterature@hit_end, published papers that evaluated Tdap coverage among HCWs, variables associated with @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake and efforts implemented to raise @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rates. We searched the @hit_startMedLine@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, SCOPUS, LILACS, Web of Science and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end for full-text studies that evaluated Tdap coverage in HCW. Two independent reviewers screened the articles and extracted the data. Twenty-eight studies published from 2009 to 2018 were reviewed. Most studies were conducted in the USA. Initial Tdap coverage varied from 6.1% to 63.9%. USA and France are the only two countries with studies evaluating Tdap coverage within HCWs using national data. In the USA, Tdap coverage in HCWs raised from 6.1% to 45.1% from 2007 to 2015. In the @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of French national data, a Tdap coverage of 63.9% was observed. Five studies used interventions to raise Tdap coverage in HCWs. Two intervention studies implemented mandatory @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and three used educational strategies. All of them achieved coverages over 86%. Only eleven studies @hit_startanalysed@hit_end the association of Tdap @hit_startvaccination@hit_end with variables of interest. Previous @hit_startimmunization@hit_end with other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end recommended for HCWs (like influenza, hepatitis B and MMR) was positively associated with Tdap uptake in four studies. In conclusion, overall Tdap coverage among HCWs is low, but seems to increase over the years after the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end introduction and with implementation of interventions to increase coverage.

titleText.ttltext: Immunogenicity and safety of the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end compared to 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide in immunocompetent adults: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of British Columbia

paras: Background: Despite the use of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PPV23) in adults there is substantial morbidity and mortality in the elderly due to pneumococcal infections. Since 2010, the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCV13) is in use for infant @hit_startimmunization@hit_end programs to reduce rates of pneumococcal disease, but is not routinely used in adults. Recent literature suggests PCV13 may be used in adult @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs as well. Objective: To determine the immunogenicity and safety of PCV13 compared with the PPV23 in adults. Design: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. Setting: Randomized controlled trials evaluating immunogenicity of a single dose of PCV13 and PPV23 in adults by the opsonophagocytic assay (OPA) geometric mean titer (GMT) response at 1-month post-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end were considered for inclusion. Results: Five randomized trials were included with 4561 subjects ranging 50–95.5 years, consisting of 51% females. The pooled OPA GMT ratio (GMTR) in the PCV13 arm was significantly higher for 10 of 13 serotypes (1, 4, 5, 6A, 6B, 9V, 18C, 19A, 19F and 23F) compared with the PPV23 arm. Overall, pooled risk ratios (RR) for local and systemic reactions did not differ between PCV13 and PPV23. Pneumococcal naïve subjects experienced significantly higher local reactions in the PCV13 arm compared with the PPV23 arm (RR: 1.15, 95%CI: 1.05–1.26, p = 0.0025). Conclusion: A single dose of PCV13 elicits a better immune response among adults compared with PPV23, while having a similar safety profile to PPV23.

titleText.ttltext: Multidisciplinary, evidence-based consensus guidelines for human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in highrisk populations, Spain, 2016

organizations: Servei de Medicina Preventiva i Epidemiologia, Hospital Universitari Vall d’Hebron, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). All rights reserved.
paras: Introduction: Although human papillomavirus (HPV) routine @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programmes have been implemented around the world and recommendations have been expanded to include other high-risk individuals, current recommendations often differ between countries in Europe, as well as worldwide. Aim: To find and summarise the best available evidence of HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in high-risk patients aiding clinicians and public health workers in the day-to-day @hit_startvaccine@hit_end decisions relating to HPV in Spain. Methods: We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the immunogenicity, safety and efficacy/effectiveness of HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in high-risk populations between January 2006 and June 2016. HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end recommendations were established with levels of evidence according to the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) system. Results: A strong recommendation about HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was made in the following groups: HIV infected patients aged 9-26 years; men who have sex with men aged 9-26 years; women with precancerous cervical lesions; patients with congenital bone marrow failure syndrome; women who have received a solid organ transplant or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation aged 9-26 years; and patients diagnosed with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis. Conclusions: Data concerning non-routine HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in populations with a high risk of HPV infection and associated lesions were scarce. We have developed a document to evaluate and establish evidence- based guidelines on HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in highrisk populations in Spain, based on best available scientific evidence.
